job_title: Registered Nurse in Chesapeake, VA
pros: Excellent company to work for - I've been with Sentara since 2001. Sentara has good benefits (although the benefit package has been revised since I started), and it cares for its people. I began working at Sentara Norfolk General Hospital (PACU and OR) and moved to the Sentara College of Health Sciences as an RN educator. Sentara's Corporate is very supportive of educating the next generation. At the College, the management team is absolutely wonderful. In this educator role (specific to taking students to the hospital for their clinical experience), I have gone to multiple Sentara facilities besides SNGH, including Sentara Careplex Hospital, Sentara Obici Hospital, Sentara Princess Anne Hospital, and Sentara Leigh Hospital. I have personally never taken students to Sentara Virginia Beach Hospital but other faculty speak highly of the facility and its people.
cons: Not so much a "con" against Sentara, however, since I graduated from nursing school 35+ years ago, the profession has always been short-staffed; there are units within Sentara's hospitals that struggle with staffing numbers. Covid didn't help that either. SNGH is a level 1 trauma center and can be a "tough crowd" - you have to know your stuff.

I am forever grateful for nurses like her - treating ncps with respect and not trolling them. some nurses there will end up giving you anxiety and panic attacks with the amount of toxicity and trolling if you complain more than once they think you are the problem also because they don't wanna lose those nurses because ncps are always replaceable.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: Pay-if your check is correct
cons:
This year alone:
Grandfathered staff not held to job description: ie no floating, no nightshift, not expected to do certain technical skills either because the skill/equipment is newer and they never bothered to learn or “it’s been too long” this puts a huge strain on the rest of the staff to cover all of their shortcomings. They sit like a bump on a log sucking up money, resources, Space and Goodwill until the shift ends.

Corporate changed HR tools. Many staff members have had their insurance canceled with no urgency from HR or management to reinstate the insurance. When insurance was reinstated over a month later, staff were back charged for the time when there was no coverage. 

This change over also wiped out vacation banks. Some co-workers were unable to pay bills because when they were on vacation, the bank was wiped with the change meaning they were not paid. Again, zero urgency to correct the issue.

Travel nurses get kicked out of the charting system when contracts are renewed. Not all of them; it’s an adventure to figure out who will not be able to chart on any given shift. 

All the med machines were replaced. This was not thought out. Patients had to hold because units had no access to medications. Also many many glitches similar to the traveler charting issue.

Staffing: one day your floor will have 12 nurses and half will be called off. The next day they will have two and beg you to come in. Sometimes this occurs within the same day.

Everything is routed through Sentara’s call center. The longest lag time I counted for a code activation was 6 minutes from the call to overhead page.

When you contact IT with an issue, you are told it is a non issue. For example don’t have access to something you need? IT either says yes you do it it’s someone else’s issue-even when that other person can show they submitted requests properly. Ap cut out and you can’t log in? You did something wrong. Is your department’s phone not receiving critical alerts (see overhead code issue above). Yes it is. They do not care that 3 people have the same issue. It is always user error.

Equipment and processes are outdated and redundant probably to keep the grandfathered staff employed.

Every day I wish I never left my old job and am actively looking for a new one. Most individual nurses and NCPs are amazing but are exhausted battling the system that makes everything 100 times more difficult every day.

Merit raises were incorrect some went negative. Holiday pay was left off of a lot of checks.

The pay is good if they actually pay you, but you will probably never have time to enjoy it. Please go into this with your eyes open.

job_title: Insurance Verification Representative in Hampton, VA
pros:
Great Healthcare
Not really any other pros
cons:
Position is dead end. You can't get anywhere in this company without a several medical degrees.
Standards and expectations for the position were always changing to be more complicated. Vacation request rules got more and more complex and esoteric often times just a few weeks before an expected vacation season.
Management was unsupportive. They didn't notice you existed unless you did something wrong- or should I say, *thought* you did something wrong. On the suspicion of you doing something wrong, they set up a gauntlet of meetings with increasingly higher managers and refused to hear anything other than a straight confession of guilt. You were pulled in on the accusation of one thing and if it didn't stick, they'd find something else.
Fellow coworkers were encouraged to suspect others of doing a bad job and report them. This led to a popularity contest. All your coworkers were breaking the rules, but if you were caught, you were reported.
So much gossip.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: Pension that is given upon Retirement if you survive that long.
cons: Sentara Urgent Care Chimney Hill is a HOSTILE work environment for all staff.   Upper Management fails to recognize and reprimand the perpetrator.  They turn a deaf ear and blind eye to the situations within the Practice.  They have allowed good staff to roll through like a revolving door and do nothing to correct the issue.  They have allowed PA's to use abusive and foul language,  manipulate situations, lie,  make obscene gestures and be aggressive towards ancillary staff.  Reporting many incidences to the practice manager has done nothing to get it under control. Writing to upper management for a resolution has only created retaliation and reprimand for coming forward.  I have witnessed nurses crying and being threatened of being fired for not following the chain of command. Following the chain of command does nothing but allow the Provider to gloat and inform the staff about no action taken.  As if they are above the law and untouchable.   It is one of the worst places I have ever worked. I would not recommend working there.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Norfolk, VA
pros: Many areas and locations to grow your career within Sentara. Being a Level I trauma center allows nurses, especially new grad nurses, to see and learn many skills and see many things that would not take place at a smaller facility.
cons: Education and career advancement come at a price. Many units are SEVERELY short staffed, nurses caring for 6 or more patients on an intermediate care unit. Charge nurses are minimally supportive, only because they are also carrying a full patient load most of the time. Complaints and concerns tend to fall on deaf ears when it comes to management. Not to mention, several managers have left their positions to return to the bedside because management "was becoming too much" and directors were being shuffled around units they were over due to poor attitudes and  ineffective leadership skills. Also, if you're of the mindset "nurses eat their young", then this is the place for you. Everyone turns a blind eye to lateral aggression among nursing staff, which is a huge factor in why nurse retention rates are so low. Also, when you let your CNAs run the show and boss the nurses around, you're bound to not be successful. Turnovers and shorter times for EVERYTHING seem to be the focus here, not actual patient care or satisfaction.

job_title: Physician Assistant in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: Lots of good people, lots of variety In positions
cons: Big company, can sometimes feel less personal

job_title: Registered Nurse in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: Management is wonderful. Great experience working here
cons: The Pay is lower than other states

job_title: Occupational Therapist in Williamsburg, VA
pros: Large organization, competitive pay, good location
cons: High productivity standards, difficult for childcare collaboration

review_title: Working at SMJH is rewarding and challenging.
job_title: Surgical Technologist in Charlottesville, VA
pros: All of the staff that I work with are compassionate and get involved with each patient's care.  Losses are mourned with the families and celebrations are cheered.  It's not just a job, it's actually caring and loving what we do.  It's Health "CARE".
cons: Not a day goes by that we are not short on staffing. Not enough is done to advertise our needs and make sure job openings are "out there".  Upper management isn't aware of our true problems and needs.  They need to reach out more to each unit, speak to people, hear what we actually deal with day to day and take action. Do not give lip service and forget us,  do something.  We don't want ice cream, we don't care about birthday gatherings and picnics with plastic cups.  We need to be heard.  We need real action.  We need change.

review_title: Great job for EMTs, recently discharged military medics and corpsmen, and nursing students.
job_title: Emergency Department Technician in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: They work with your schedule to an extent for school. The leadership has daily huddles to pass info and receive feedback from employees. New staffing angel online system is working well. Leadership does have an open door policy.
cons: Favoritism can be bad, and I've seen some nurses leave because of it. Some habitually late employees still have jobs. When your coworkers have a problem with you, they tell everyone else except you, and then it shows up on your annual evaluation. Turnover rate for Clin II nurses is high so there are voids in management. A few charge nurses allow their friends to loiter, and smoke outside while others are told to work.

review_title: I will look for a healthcare company to values ALL of their employees!
job_title: Nursing Care Partner in Norfolk, VA
pros: Decent healthcare benefits, largest employer to work for, many locations.
cons: Policies are enforced based on the employee's relationship with management, transferring policies, medical leave policies, slow recruitment turn around, pregnancy policies.

review_title: Review of Sentara Laboratory: Good First Job Experience that has Taught me to Strive for More as a Medical Technologist
job_title: Medical Technologist in Virginia Beach, VA
pros:
Some Techs received sign on bonuses. 
Pathologists can be very helpful.
Most coworkers are hardworking
cons:
Management may not be a good advocate for the med tech.
Most techs get hired as 0.9 FTE, most of the time you will work your 80 hours per pay check but be ready to lose one day of work if management feels that they are not meeting productivity numbers and want to cut down on POSSIBLE overtime.
Frequent sick call outs from coworkers means that coverage may or may not be priority and some techs have to work 2 departments throughout the shift.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Suffolk, VA
pros: Growth potential. Great co-workers. Great place to build lasting business relationships. Most of the departments have a "teamwork " attitude. Sentara has several core values that are taught, a lot of them can spill over into your personal life, and help mold you into a better focused person.
cons: Sometimes, being under the wrong manager can make going to work hard! We lost a valuable manager in the department I worked in; and got a "she-devil". Employees that had been with the company for YEARS, all of a sudden began to leave. Several of the employees began looking for other work, and going to work was no longer a nice place to be. When this new manager left the department, for higher ground, things got a bit better, but not much.

job_title: Education Specialist in Williamsburg, VA
pros: Sentara is growing!  I started when we were just a community hospital and Sentara came along and bought us.  Since then Sentara has added a few hospitals making a total of 12 hospitals.  We go from Northern VA to North Carolina.  They treat you very well, the benefits are awesome, and we get a bonus every year.  I have so much PAL time every year, too.  The hospital that I work at is in Williamsburg and I can honestly say that I feel very much like those who work there are like my second family.
cons: With newer leadership (6 years or less), I see a little bit of power struggle (flexing of power muscles).  I just hope they see that things are running perfectly and they shouldn't change a thing.

job_title: Physical Therapist in Norfolk, VA
pros:
You get to collaborate with different health professions for interdisciplinary approach in helping patients get better. The work environment is great with fun coworkers and motivated people. It's a family feel when you work there. Left the company due to a move with my spouse's transfer.
You can say you're proud of being an Sentara employee.
cons:
They are not strict as in compromise your salary, but possibly performance review if you don't meet certain units. There are different factors in how you may or may not miss it. The way it's calculated is not always fair with some people having easier time meeting the number. It does put a bit of stress. 
Financial support towards professional growth or belonging to a professional organization is not the best, but it is there. 
Be prepared to work some weekends and Holidays! Comp days, compensation is there, so not a true Con. It is what it is. You don't have to get approval for having Holiday off, but you will use your PTO time.

job_title: Health/Fitness Instructor in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: Free gym membership and a few close friends.
cons: The Wellness Center is FULL of drama. During the pandemic the center was shut down and employees were "given the option" to work at the hospital screening potential COVID patients and working in a very high risk environment with little to no necessary equipment. While they worded this work as an "opportunity" it quickly turned into a requirement. If you were an employee unwilling to work for the lowered wages and increased risk you were bumped from part-time to "flexi" meaning they never had to work you again. This caused many employees to quit. Favorites are chosen by management at the center and if you are not a favorite then do not talk to anyone. Everyone is a snake in the grass attempting to work their way up the ladder.

job_title: Administrative Associate in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: Pay and yearly bonuses are good, benefits are good, training is very thorough.  Management seems to be very understanding concerning work schedule, family concerns or health issues.
cons: That said, favoritism is out of control.  Manager can be rude, crude, sarcastic, and quite difficult to deal with when in a bad mood. If management gets upset with an employee or one of his/her favorites decides to to put a bug in his/her ear they become relentless  in trying to get them written up and fired.

review_title: Be mindful, be steadfast, document everything, protect yourself!
job_title: Senior LAN/SAN/WAN Integrator in Norfolk, VA
pros: Okay pay, Okay benefits, good as a first job, if you have no other options or for people who enjoy documenting and justifying their every move?
cons: Un-necessarily stressful (every decision is life-or-death), Management by fear, Micro-management (Bathrooms are not safe), Rampant un-professional behavior, company expects dedication and flexibility but offer none in return, not a good long-term career decision for most, not for professionals who expect professionalism.  They've fired someone only weeks away from retirement and took their retirement away.  Expect that when they say employment is at-will, they mean it and they will always make you aware of that..  They rely on known in-accurate reports to allow them to fire you at will with justification.  If you cross any management best believe they will have a report they can and likely will fire you for.

job_title: Patient Care Specialist in Chesapeake, VA
pros: Overall I enjoyed my time at Sentara healthcare for 19 years.  I worked in many locations in different positions within the company.  What I liked most were their benefits and getting rehired.  I separated from Sentara 4 times and if you leave on good terms you will have no problem getting rehired.  The working conditions weren't bad neither were the working hours.  Inter office communications were good and there were many staff meetings.  All in all I would go back again because even though there are faults Sentara is a great place to work.
cons: Some locations had better supervisors than others and also better communication among employees.  Many times they were under staffed and training was inadequate and brief. Also getting time off was difficult especially personal emergencies ir just a personal day off.

job_title: Catering Associate in Virginia Beach, VA
pros:
if you are good at multi tasking, have a good work ethic, and know how to work together with the nurses and your team you will prosper even in the crappy conditions there may be.
-decent pay
-work 2 and a half 12 hours days and every other weekend
-immediate coworkers tend to work together
cons:
-management is all over the place sometimes
-workload tends to always be heavy
-a lot of running around 
-you will be drained by the end of the shift mentally and physically
-not much support from management
-management truly doesn't know what the workload is like as a catering associate, they should have asked the CA's their opinions of the new team building program before truly implimenting it. Really think they just wanted to save money

job_title: Registered Nurse in Norfolk, VA
pros: Beautiful new units. Great nurse-MD collaboration. Friendly staff. Updated technology making easier charting. Yearly Bonus and yearly pay raise. Great benefits.
cons: Nurse/patient ration on most floors can be up to 1/7. Pay could be much better. Poor management. Nurse needs are often overlooked and unheard to meet a "budget" or the requests of attending physicians (what ortho wants, ortho gets). Unwilling to hire adequate staff.

review_title: Good work environment lack of management
job_title: Emergency Department Technician in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: 3 years working in the emergency department at a newly owned Sentara facility recent take over from being a community hospital. Great brand new facility and great people to work with. Very flexible with scheduling, trades, and shift changes.
cons: Only facility in the area so there is no pay negotiation which allows them to pay lower. Supplies, policies and procedures as well as management direction is constantly changing as we move from what used to be a community hospital to a non-profit healthcare system owned facility. With all the policy changes there seems to be different rules for different people and changes to depending on when you ask.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: The only pro that I can really come up with would be that the company does actually pay well for this area.
cons: Everything is silos.  Managers and employees in each department only care about whatever piece of a project or task is THEIR responsibility. "That's not my job" is a phrase that is heard on a daily basis.  Management was condescending and only concerned about the bottom line. Not unusual for a big corporation, it's just not how things were at the hospital before Sentara bought it out in 2010.  Sad.

job_title: in Newport News, VA
pros: The patients are a pro because I like helping them and meeting different types of people. Co workers are cool for the most part.  All though the paycheck is small it's still a paycheck I guess.
cons: Management/Team Coordinators are terrible. They gossip and talk about everyone including each other. They enjoy getting people in trouble. They don't want you to take vacations. Their only focus is to find what your doing wrong even when you doing so many other things right.  They don't care about anyone but themselves and display a basic lack of listening skills. Backstabbing all day .None of their "great ideas" are ever great. Pay could be higher for all you deal with. I could go on and on but it's not worth the energy.

job_title: Staff RN in Norfolk, VA
pros: Management seems to be interested in my experience and feed back.  Co-workers seem to value my opinion.  I'm already trained/exposed to a new role within my department.
cons:
The culture of the department seems to normally staff with a "crisis mindset".  Staffing ratios are unsafe and I worry about my ability to be a patient advocate and provide excellent care due to the assignments I'm given.  I have spoken to management about my concerns and given possible solutions.  Nothing has change at this point.  

My salary with the amount of experience I have is a joke.

review_title: I worked direct patient care as a Nursing Care Partner (basically a Nurses Aide with more training and responsibilities)
job_title: Nursing Care Partner in Norfolk, VA
pros: Excellent benefits: has a 403b plan versus a 401k, so you can put away about 3x more for retirement; healthcare plan is better than many of the other employers in the area.
cons: Direct patient care works on a "grid system" X# of patients requires Y# of Care Partners and Nurses, unfortunately, whoever came up with this system obviously never worked as a patient care provider because the ratio of patients to providers is too high for safe patient care.

review_title: The worst job I ever had!
job_title: Patient Care Representative in Norfolk, VA
pros: The benefits packages are awesome.
cons: There isn't a lot of room for growth, the management is incompetent, the pay is substantially lower than the national market rate, employee moral is very low, there are a lot cliques, the culture sucks, and employees do not have a voice. I spoke up about a patient privacy issue and was black balled by management. When I applied for a transfer my manager blocked the transfer on two occasions and basically made my life a living hell. I quit before finding another job.

job_title: Buyer in Chesapeake, VA
pros: Great company to work, great benefits, the pay is good also.
cons: In my department there are too many Managers and Directors...9 to be exact for about 40 people. The whole structure makes no sense. Limited room for growth and too often there is nepotism & favoritism when it's time for a promotion. Seems to be the dumping ground for nepotists and their friends and family. Fear of change has kept this department in the stone age.

review_title: Looks good in the beginning but not good once your get in.....especially when benefits are cancelled.
job_title: Clinical Specialist Rockingham Memorial Hospital in Norfolk, VA
pros: Decent pay, easy parking, no traffic, lower cost of living in Harrisonburg, Va area
cons: Company owns the health insurance company and cancels your insurance within days of your notice. The postmark on the insurance cancellation was after the insurance was cancelled? Leaving me with no insurance after the 12th of the month and NO advanced notice of cancellation. Other things: Generally no breaks, frequent last minute schedule changes to an already rotating schedule, lack of patient care or employee safety, lack of care by employees, no educational opportunities, negative work environment, its about the bottom line unfortunately.

review_title: Staff satisfaction is not in thier game plan.
job_title: RN IV Emergency Department in Woodbridge, VA
pros: The facility is close to I-95.
cons: The leaders are out of the loop from their staff. They chase away the good, higher paying nurses so they can hire less experinced  nurses at non-NOrhtern VA rates. Several nurses lost of 15 dollars per hour.

job_title: EDT in Virginia Beach, VA
pros:
Benefits
Scheduling is easy
Hours are there if you want them
cons:
Poor ED management
The "higher-ups" for the most part, in the ED are very much a clique and do as they please, when they want and the people they're friends with get to sit back and reap the benefits.

job_title: Clinical Staff in Hampton, VA
pros: Sentara has a lot of jobs, advancement and good benefits. They have good health schools and many different kinds of doctors.
cons: Sentara has poor management, alot of backbiting, a lack of respect for its workers. Each manager seems to have pets and some of the doctors are abnormal , out of control people and the hospital automatically supports them and not you because the bottom line with Sentara is always the dollar and doctors bring in the money.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: Retirement and pension, I love helping people, I get to work with a great team, I like the flexible scheduling.
cons: The pay seems minimal, nursing care partners don't get the same benefits as other employees. Of course RNs get paid more, but we should recieve the same shift differential, we should recieve extra pay for working only weekends, and we should recieve extra pay for precepting a new employee.

review_title: Excellent benefits, good place to work.
job_title: Registered Nurse in Norfolk, VA
pros: Great benefits -- Sentara has a has a pension plan, tuition assistance, and 403B. Not too many companies nowadays have a pension plan.  There are many opportunities for growth. In my department, the leadership is very supportive and caring. Sentara has great training and education.  Employee discount at the cafeteria.  Many opportunities for volunteering and community involvement.
cons: The hospitals are grossly understaffed.  The pay is quite low compared to cost of living in Hampton Roads, but it is higher than other hospital systems in the area.  Sentara does not compensate for the cost of certification exams.

job_title: Nurse in Elizabeth City, NC
pros: Feels like family. Small rural hospital.
cons: Not very many learning opportunities. Routinely inadequately staffed. Very many call outs due to nurses and NCPs being burned out from high acuity patient loads. You can count on spending at least 3-4 hours charting (hate the charting system), never having a break, and leaving well after your shift has concluded. Like any place, there are a few nurses that have worked there for years that are very sour. Often have a hard time being able to read up on patients because you don’t have time which is scary. Doctors are difficult to get in contact with even for urgent situations.

review_title: 4 years at Sentara as an RN, in 3 different divisions
job_title: Home Care, Hospital Nurse, Outpatient Setting in Norfolk, VA
pros: Mandatory paid continuing ed for nurses.  Relatively good benefits and pay for the area of Hampton Roads.  Ability to move between jobs in the Sentara system
cons: Each employee is expected to do the job of 2 employees.  Sentara, a highly profitable non-profit corporation, focuses on the bottom line and employees are driven to perform beyond normally accepted case loads and standards.  In my opinion, this does not lead to enhanced patient safety or positive patient outcomes as Sentara touts. Magnet status-I just do not know how this has been achieved for SNGH or will be achieved for other Sentara facilities.

job_title: Laboratory Technician in Woodbridge, VA
pros: You are making a difference in somebody life
cons:
Lab at northern Virginia medical center is filled with nothing other than backstabbing 
Gossiping, unprofessional and nasty attitude staff , they will make you feel unwelcome your first day in addition to lack of knowledge they try to micromanage  new employee and make them feel uvaluable. Management is weak and only care about themselves .
Computer system is so complicated  yet archaic. 
Staff focus on tiny negative things and a big dislike between different shift.
 Lack of communication and speaking is not allowed stabbing in the back is what goes around.
Work load is high with short staff is every day challenge .
No training available and they expect you to know every thing and no questions are welcome which make it stressful environment to work..
Believe me never work there , it is not  a good place for medical technologist , if you do write your negative reviews here to benifit others

review_title: Picking up and delivering specimens, etc!
job_title: Courier in Norfolk, VA
pros: Benefits, maybe. Decent pay. No weekends yet.
cons: Long hours, no set route, training with different trainers and different takes on standards such as what cooler does a specimen go into; room, refrigerated, frozen. Lots of confusion especially identifying specimens for new hires. Float as in Sentara speak means 'Rotating' so if you get a job as a courier and the position states rotating, clarify to the hiring manager what that means so you do not get screwed being a FLOAT unless that is what you want. Training on various routes can become taxing on the mind and body trying to remember all the stops within the stops.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Woodbridge, VA
pros: Co-workers were great, but that's about it.
cons: Administration is clueless and greed driven. The nurse:patient ratios are DANGEROUS! Nurses and NCPs get reprimanded for voicing concerns. Management only looks out for themselves and as long as their units look good on paper, that's all they care about.

job_title: Business Systems Analyst in Norfolk, VA
pros:
-Decent benefits
-No Layoffs
-Mostly friendly teams
-promote from within
cons:
-Monopoly on Health IT in the region, no other options to work in the field without being open to extensive travel
-No flex time, it is determined per team and manager, some teams get extensive work from home time during holidays other teams only in case of emergency (applied only to IT)
-Very little training offered, or options for certification/vendor training
-Poor all around project management, employees are hired based on technical skill but PM work is required in the job, there is little to no training to compensate for this
-Lower range on the pay scale for titles, and very little chance to increase other than moving high into upper management, even they are underpaid

job_title: Registered Nurse in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: Great learning opportunities and potential for growth
cons:
-The pay is not as high as other area hospitals
-Management does nothing to head off staffing shortages and does not listen to employees telling them there is an issue
-A position has to be vacated before they will fill it so that position is not actually filled for 2-4 months

job_title: Nurse Care Partner-Medical Surge in Chesapeake, VA
pros: Being @ people who needs to be listened by ones (like me) to take control and allow their experience they're going through/and or WILL be figuring it through....that people like ME, are always here to help through ANYTHING and EVERYTHING I know they know and must recognize That I KNOW & UNDERSTAND AND I AM HERE FOR THEM  PERIOD. ....
cons: Too much for one person to me ripped n raved every which way, all over entire floor.  Also between 4 different RNs

review_title: Uncomfortable, unwelcoming and more of burden than an asset as a new employee!!!!!
job_title: Nursing Care Partner in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: Management acted as if they really tried to make you feel welcome. The benefits offered were better than  most companies.
cons: Definitely not a welcoming environment. The floor staff definitely need to be educated on how to be a positive mentor. Very "cliquish" work culture. Expect to be treated as an outcast and feel ridiculed if you ask questions. This experience has caused me give up on a position in healthcare after 20 years in the field. Unless you a very overly confident personality DO NOT bother applying; it will break your spirit!!!!

job_title: Senior Patient Account Representative in Chesapeake, VA
pros: The company general reputation.  Ranking nationally in 2 adult specialties.  High-performing in 5 adult specialties.  Did you know that Sentara Norfolk General Hospital is a 495-bed general medical and surgical facility with 25,715 admissions in the most recent year reported?  Performing 9,199 annual inpatient and 9,807 outpatient surgeries.  The emergency room had 71,555 visits.
cons: I looking for a better career prospects, professional growth and work opportunities.  Also, a change in career direction.  Looking for new challenges at work.

review_title: IT department is a downward spiral
job_title: IT Engineer in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: Paid well (but not enough to tolerate the negative aspects, not even close). Sometimes free leftover Panera in the break room. Conveniently located/decent commute.
cons: Chief Enterprise Architect and CTO are charlatans. Employees not empowered to do much of anything. Unrealistic demands placed on employees due to senior level IT dept leadership being absolutely clueless when it comes to how technology actually works and is implemented. IT procurement decisions are being made based on personal interest/gain and not what's best for the organization.

job_title: Hospital Registration in Lorton, VA
pros: The company is a great place for patients. The care I have seen at this hospital is much better than other area hospitals. Customer service and patient care go hand in hand here.
cons: The company has very expensive insurance. The company has little follow through when opening up a new facility.

job_title: Critical Care RN in Norfolk, VA
pros: Depends what unit you work on.  There are six ICU's.  General, Neuro, Burn/trauma, Vascular, Cardiology, and Cardiac Surgery.  Each are different.  Burnout is high in burn/trauma and cardiac surgery from my experience with turnover frequently 1-2 years, due to patient acuity and workload.  Other nurses have said general and vascular have many nurse there 10-20 years.  Resource nurses make even more but be ready to work in step-down units more often than ICU.  Management has been supportive.
cons: Pay is low across the region, however you can make decent pay with differentials. $4/hrs nights and $6/hrs weekend.  Some units offer call-pay which is time-and-a-half for additional shifts.

job_title: Outpatient Coder in Woodbridge, VA
pros: Job stability, benefits are good, lots of job openings, the doctors are great & most people working there are very good at what they do & great to work with.
cons: No way to grow in your career path, practice management are unorganized, rude & no matter what you do your wrong. And every day you will be made to feel this way. Lots of job openings because they can't keep people around. You will wear lots of "hats" & will not be compensated or recognized on your review. Evaluation time is just another time to be told what you've done wrong all year.

job_title: Case Manager in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: Teams you work with are great. You have some very educated, competent people that are employees at Sentara.
cons: The peoplw up top don't seem to have a clue about the front line workers. They end up losing excellent employees due  to adding more responsibilities than possible within the timeframe allowed. Always ask about the fine print with this company!

job_title: Nurse in Norfolk, VA
pros: Excellent benefits, health, dental, vision plans and paid leave and sick time. Decent pay. Opportunities to transfer, for some positions, and maintain benefits.
cons: Because their are opportunities to transfer and maintain employment, there is excessive turnover in many departments causing frequent stress for staff. New employees get shorted on having experienced staff to orient them. This perpetuates a cycle of turnover and short staffing .

review_title: Great company with many opportunities and benefits!!!
job_title: Senior Patient Account Representative in Chesapeake, VA
pros: Sentara offers many career opportunities, yearly evaluations/increases/cost of living increases when applicable. They also have been successful in no lay offs even with today's economic challenges. Great benefits including tuition assistance, 403 k plan, and pension. My only regret is not joining the Sentara team earlier in my career.
cons: There are many downsides working with Sentara as there is with any place of employment. They try to address them but not always successful for many reasons.

job_title: IT Manager in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: great place to work, always on the leading edge of technology.  Management really care about their staff and do everything they can to recognize the contributions made by the team.
cons: very complex IT shop.. many apps integrated and many of the APP Owners struggle speaking in terms that the Tech staff understand.  it is a constant challenge to work through the translations.

job_title: Executive Director Registration Coordinator in Woodbridge, VA
pros: Staff, work perks, patients, pay AWESOME
cons: Lack of recognition from Administration, staff and staffing

job_title: Administrative Associate in Hampton, VA
pros: Health benefits are very good. Pay is better than other local hospitals. Team environment overall. Flexible schedule. Continued education is encouraged and financial aid is available. Ability to advance within the company.
cons: Managers had a tendency to favor some employees over others and consequences were not equal at times. Many times not enough staff to cover all sections and employees unable to have significant breaks and/or lunch or dinner breaks.

job_title: IT Help Desk in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: The only good thing about working for Sentara was the monetary compensation. That is the only good think I can say.
cons: Sentara is a horrible organization to work for unless you need money really badly. I came into Sentara from one of the hospitals they bought out, and immediately they were talking about getting rid of me because my vast range of IT knowledge did not fit into there little world. Although they did keep me I was immediately put into a cube farm and it went downhill from there. Most of the staff in the Help Desk are extremely uneducated which just dragged the overall performance way down.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: Great benefits, a large corporation overall with opportunities to move within the system to advance your career. Yet each hospital is its own sort of family, very different making it feel like a small, close knit community.
cons: When you have a complaint, there is definitely that big corporation feeling that sneaks in. Change is always slow, but the supervisors I have had over the years were always open to my advice and listened. Even if it never came to fruition, I felt heard.

job_title: Administrative Associate  in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: Has the largest healthcare footprint in the area.
cons: Sentara plays a lot of lip service to being an employer of choice, but this is so very far from the truth.  There are levels of unethical behavior that are tolerated and in fact encouraged in all departments.  Rather than correct mistakes employees are encouraged to create "spin" to justify the results.  This behavior exists in all levels and departments.  Management turns a blind eye to the low employee morale.  Advancement, transfers, perks, etc. are doled out to management favorites without regard to work performance or job ability.  Every department/division has an "us against them" mentality, so there is a lot of infighting.

review_title: A great company that may be growing a little too fast...
job_title: Reimbursement Consultant in Norfolk, VA
pros: Great benefits and salaries; still offer a PENSION; never have layoffs -- very impressive.
cons: Foresight may be too aggressive for current staff; No mentor program or apparent desire to develop leaders; active rumor-mill

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Virginia Beach, VA
pros:
I will be paying just under $400 a month for 6 people to have top of the line health insurance including dental and vision.  I will also have discounted copays if I use a Sentara facility.
There's several other benefits such as Flex spending accounts which eliminates tax on daycare costs. Life insurance, tuition reimbursements and more. They also pay for my continuing education credits and BLS/CPR certifications.
cons: Pay is less competitive than some places but if you factor in the benefits, it is worth it to me.

job_title: RN, Bsn in Portsmouth, VA
pros: Consistent hours. Efficient team. Competent leadership. Readily available resources. Hospital structure is pleasant airy, private rooms. Well stocked and userfriendly medication system. Convenient travel from home.
cons: The rate of patient turnover is very high so that our unit is fast paced. As a result the staff turnover is high as a lot of new nurses that  get hired become overwhelmed and quit. This often increases the nurse to patient ratio and the environment becomes stressful. Additionally there is added tasks when the nurse assistant calls out with no replacement which happens often.

job_title: Admitting Representative in Hampton, VA
pros: The benefits are pretty decent.
cons: They lie on their employees and throw them under the bus to save face. Sentara is all about numbers over patient care. They implement all these policies that are bogus in the emergency dept where I worked. These policies and procedures are going to ultimately kill someone one day.  The ED registration supervisor was mentally disturbed and always had a chip on her shoulder. She also threw her own employees under the bus for HER mistakes instead of owning up to her actions. And no advancement opportunities because management writes you up for every little thing.

review_title: Worked as emergency room medical technician
job_title: Medical Tech in Woodbridge, VA
pros: I worked at Potomac Hospital (now Sentara Hospital). It was a good place to work for the most part. I worked nights and most of my co-workers were nice people. Food in cafeteria was pretty good. It was always busy and fast paced and I learned a lot.
cons: Management was awful, very demanding and didn't listen or sympathize with staff. Pay was not great and some of the patients were extremely rude.

job_title: Nursing Care Partner in Hampton, VA
pros: Everyone has been so welcoming and helpful as a new employee. Each person I have worked with on different floors have been great about helping with patient care and I feel blessed to be working at a great hospital!

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Chesapeake, VA

job_title: Registered Nurse in Woodbridge, VA
pros: - Co-workers (or what's left of them) : Supportive, encouraging and will always help you in time of need. With the floor almost always being understaffed, you will develop a sense of teamwork and bond.
cons:
- Education: Prepare to self-learn. Nurse residency program is useless. The only thing they do to encourage  to extend your knowledge is tell you to complete the yearly CBT required modules.   
- Self-scheduling: Great concept, but basically USELESS when your preferred shifts are modified due to the floor ALWAYS being understaffed. The floor is 80% travel/float nurses, while all the senior RN's have been let-go for vindictive reasons. NCP's schedules are changed without notice or communication. RN's are constantly pressured to pick-up OT to make-up for the high turn-over rate caused by management. 
- New grads are oriented by new nurses who have less than 2yr experience or straight out of orientation...no comment.
- The floor is under-staffed always but expect unrealistic job expectations.  (ex. 1:7 pt ratio with ZERO techs, yet they expect everyone to be dry and clean by morning, drop everything and run to every bed alarm, have all your labs and vitals done by yourself, turn and reposition all your total pts while still maintaining to do a NCP/RN job duties, etc.)
*** High-turn over rate: People can't make it past the 1st three months off orientation. Work environment isn't ideal, new NCP's have been thrown into the 50-bed floor to work by themselves on the first weeks of their solo schedule. Some have even been thrown in without the guidance of their preceptor.  DO NOT BELIEVE THEM WHEN THEY TELL YOU THE RATIO IS 5-6 PATIENTS PER NURSE. IT IS A LIE. YOU WILL HAVE 7-8 PATIENTS AND AT TIMES WITHOUT A NCP/TECH SUPPORT. CHARGE RN's ARE RUNNING WITH 7 PATIENTS. THIS IS THE NORM.
- Career Opportunities and advancement: Some will flat-out tell you that you're unqualified and not ready to transition to a different unit because of desperation to keep you on the floor. An employee was held for 5 months prior to transitioning, who's had years of experience and was told they "aren't ready." Will go behind your back and try to ruin your chances before you can transfer out. 
- Favoritism / Racism: There is a certain preference and if you fit it, you will survive on this floor. You will have your choices heard and followed and you can practically get away with anything while someone less favorable gets thrown under the bus for you.

job_title: CMA in Chesapeake, VA
pros: Whatever you do for Sentara Medical Group, it is never good enough.   The  patients were wonderful and it was a pleasure to assist them however possible for a good office visit. cons: You are ridiculed for everything.  Nothing is ever good enough.  Whom ever trains you, they may have shown you how to do things but you don't perform the job the way you learned.  How would a manager know that when she is running like a chicken with her head cut off between two practices? She is rarely at the office where I was assigned to work.  The manager doesn't know what confidentiality is, sharing very private and confidential matters with the entire staff of the practice PLUS, the Vascular and Podiatry side of where I worked.  Sentara Medical Group also hires assaultive bullies.  Wile it is to be a ZERO tolerance for assaulting people and bullying, I was subjected to both and the assaultive bully was kept while I was terminated.  If there is no one to talk with and investigate an incident, how can you come to a termination conclusion?  It was WRONGFUL TERMINATION and done while my immediate manager was on vacation.  They also make certain there is no way to access upper management to file a complaint.  Your personal times accrued MUST be taken when the physician is not at the office to work so you lose your accumulated time very easily....
